verses.text: He has founded His city on the holy mountains;
verses.comment: The 'holy mountains' refer to Zion, the spiritual and physical center of God’s chosen people. Many early Christian writers viewed this as a foreshadowing of the heavenly city, the ultimate gathering place of all believers.

verses.text: The LORD loves the gates of Zion more than all the dwellings of Jacob.
verses.comment: Zion, representing God’s chosen dwelling, surpasses even the rest of Israel's places. This hints at the unique role of God's holy assembly and anticipates the New Testament teaching about the Church as the new spiritual Zion (Heb. 12:22).

verses.text: Glorious things are spoken of you, O city of God. Selah
verses.comment: 'City of God' alludes to a city not just built by hands, but where God Himself dwells. The prophecy is both literal (Jerusalem) and spiritual, pointing to the gathering of God’s people, fulfilled in the Body of Christ and its unity. The 'Selah' reminds the reader to pause and reflect on this divine mystery.

verses.text: I will mention Rahab and Babylon among those who know Me—Philistia, Tyre, and Cush—'This one was born there,' they say.
verses.comment: Rahab is a poetic name for Egypt; Babylon, Philistia, Tyre, Cush—all classic Gentile nations—are included among those who come to know God. This anticipates the bringing in of the Gentiles into God’s people, a theme expounded in the New Testament (Eph. 2:13-19). Their spiritual rebirth in Zion hints at sacraments that initiate believers into God’s family.

verses.text: But of Zion it will be said, 'This one and that one were born in her.' And the Most High Himself will establish her.
verses.comment: This affirms that true citizenship in the city of God is by spiritual birth, echoing Jesus’ teaching on being 'born again' (John 3:3). The idea that the Lord Himself establishes Zion points to the divine origin and protection of God’s one holy assembly.

verses.text: The LORD will record, when He counts the peoples, 'This one was born there.' Selah
verses.comment: God Himself registers the names of those born in Zion. This evokes the biblical concept of the Book of Life (Rev. 21:27). This passage points toward a sacramental view of spiritual rebirth through incorporation into God’s community.

verses.text: Both singers and dancers will say, 'All my springs are in you.'
verses.comment: The springs symbolize the source of life and joy found within God’s city. This connects with Christ’s promise of living water (John 7:37-39), which flows from God’s presence to the believer. The image also prefigures the liturgical life and worship at the heart of the Christian community.
